newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican stocks close strong on speculation.
newsitem.headline: Mexican stocks close strong on speculation.

text.p: Mexican stocks closed nearly two percent higher Wednesday, bolstered by speculative buying of industrial and construction stocks, traders said.
"Construction stocks were in demand again due to construction spending outlined in the state of the nation speech (on Sunday), but volume was thin," a floor trader said.
The IPC index of blue-chip stocks closed 63 points or 1.93 percent higher to 3,329.99 points.
President Ernesto Zedillo in his state of the nation speech pledged an estimated 14 billion pesos for restructuring highway finances hit by the 1994 peso devaluation.

"I felt the market was very speculative ahead of U.S. unemployment data, which are what will determine stock market behaviour in the U.S. and Mexico next week," said a trader from the BBV-Probursa brokerage.
The U.S. Department of Labor will release unemployment data for August on Friday.
"The U.S. bond market is reflecting expectations of the unemployment data, which may push yields up," another trader said.
The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond closed at 7.10 percent, up from 7.08 percent in early trade.
"Buying was partly due to foreign investors who are very liquid from the (stock) boom of some weeks ago, but are very selective when they enter the market," the BBV-Probursa trader said.
A total of 96 stocks changed hands, 57 of which gained and 18 lost, with the remaining 21 unchanged. Volume was light at 69.5 million shares.
Heavily-weighted Telmex L series shares closed up 34 centavos at 12.74 pesos.
According to the James Capel brokerage, the IPC has a resistance, in dollar terms, at 455 points. (corrects figure.)
